P.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union.
It also resolves as positive if by the same deadline the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name

Q.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Zermelo's theorem says that only one of three possibilities is possible in a 2-player solved game; First player (white) wins, second player (black) wins, or there is a forced draw.
In the game of chess, these outcomes correspond to:
White wins
Black wins
Forced draw
If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
For the purpose of this question, chess is considered to be solved if
it is proved that white will win, lose or draw from the initial position, given perfect play on both sides
it is shown that there exists a unique result of perfect play from the initial position, which is either: white wins, black wins, or forced draw
Resolution is by publication of peer-reviewed article that is not shown to be mistaken for at least 3 years post-publication.
For the purpose of this question, the 50-move rule does not force a draw. Games that don't end, are considered drawn, for the purpose of this question
This question resolves ambiguously if the question does not resolve before Jan 1st, 2080.

P_or_Q.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027 or if chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur (or both). a.) Before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union, or the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name. OR b.) If chess is solved before 2080, and it is proved that perfect play from the initial position results in white winning. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning, or will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur (or both). a.) If chess is solved before 2080 and it is proved that perfect play results in white winning OR b.) Before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon or the European Union dissolves completely or into a new union. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union.
It also resolves as positive if by the same deadline the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name

metadata.background_info:
Anti-European sentiment is running strong in the EU and it may grow stronger – strong enough to destroy it, maybe? The UK voted for Brexit and political pundits are already discussing Nexit, Frexit and Quitaly.
Some commentators argue that Brexit is already the end of the EU as we know it, some would say that Brexit may be fine but if any other country was to leave would spell the end of the union. We choose an even stricter criterion by requiring then one of the 6 original founders of the ECSC leave the union to decree the end of the EU as we know it.

Q.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Zermelo's theorem says that only one of three possibilities is possible in a 2-player solved game; First player (white) wins, second player (black) wins, or there is a forced draw.
In the game of chess, these outcomes correspond to:
White wins
Black wins
Forced draw
If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
For the purpose of this question, chess is considered to be solved if
it is proved that white will win, lose or draw from the initial position, given perfect play on both sides
it is shown that there exists a unique result of perfect play from the initial position, which is either: white wins, black wins, or forced draw
Resolution is by publication of peer-reviewed article that is not shown to be mistaken for at least 3 years post-publication.
For the purpose of this question, the 50-move rule does not force a draw. Games that don't end, are considered drawn, for the purpose of this question
This question resolves ambiguously if the question does not resolve before Jan 1st, 2080.

P.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

Q.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Data for resolution shall be taken from the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list (note: of course the link currently does not lead to the 2033 list). Note that this list is to be differentiated from the real time list.

P_or_Q.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100 or will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur (or both). a.) There has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years by January 1, 2100, where the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880 OR b.) The richest person in the world in 2033 has a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time or will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur (or both). a.) The richest person in the world in 2033 has a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time OR b.) There has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years by January 1, 2100, in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

metadata.background_info: At the Paris climate accord, world leaders promised to keep the global temperature increase this century (relative to pre-industrial levels) "well below 2 ˚C" and if possible below 1.5 ˚C. Many experts are skeptical about this goal being feasible, stating that even if all Paris targets are met, global warming may reach levels up to 3 ˚C above pre-industrial levels. Furthermore, with the coming departure of the United States from the agreement, the meeting of global targets may be in jeopardy.

Q.title: Will the richest person in the world in 2033 have a net worth equivalent to or greater than 2% of the United States' GDP at the time?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Data for resolution shall be taken from the 2033 Forbes Billionaires list (note: of course the link currently does not lead to the 2033 list). Note that this list is to be differentiated from the real time list.

metadata.background_info:
John D. Rockefeller is considered to be the wealthiest American of all time. In 1913 he was the world's richest person with a net worth of over a billion dollars. That was equivalent to about 2% of the United States' GDP back then. For reference, 2% of US GDP would be close to 400 billion dollars today! This reference perspective makes him much richer than the current richest person in the world, Jeff Bezos, whose net worth is at 112 billion dollars in the 2018 Forbes ranking.
Yet, inequality is on the rise in many developed countries and the net worth of the richest person in the world has been consistently increasing over the last few years. Could a person as rich as John D. Rockefeller reappear in the modern world?

P.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union.
It also resolves as positive if by the same deadline the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name

Q.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

P_or_Q.title: Will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027 or will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P_or_Q.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur (or both): a.) Before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union, or the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name. b.) Between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris. Resolves NO otherwise.

Q_or_P.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050 or will any of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany leave the EU before 2027?
Q_or_P.body: Resolves YES if either of these events occur: a.) Between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris OR b.) Before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union, or the European Union has dissolved completely or transformed into a new politico-economic union under a different name. Resolves NO otherwise.

Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2027, one or more of Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, and/or Germany triggers Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon by notifying the European Council of its intention to leave the union.
It also resolves as positive if by the same deadline the entity called European Union has dissolved completely or dissolved to create a new politico-economic union of some European nations under a different name

Anti-European sentiment is running strong in the EU and it may grow stronger – strong enough to destroy it, maybe? The UK voted for Brexit and political pundits are already discussing Nexit, Frexit and Quitaly.
Some commentators argue that Brexit is already the end of the EU as we know it, some would say that Brexit may be fine but if any other country was to leave would spell the end of the union. We choose an even stricter criterion by requiring then one of the 6 original founders of the ECSC leave the union to decree the end of the EU as we know it.

Q.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

metadata.background_info:
The Kessler syndrome is a situation where a major satellite collision causes an increase in space junk, causing a cascading effect destroying many if not most other satellites.
As of 2018, we are losing about one satellite per year due to collisions with space junk, yet these collisions are far too small to cause a runaway effect. Furthermore, action has been taken by the Federal Communications Commission to reduce the chance of this happening and regulations in the US require all satellites launched after March 18, 2002 to be disposed of by controlled atmospheric reentry or a boost into a graveyard orbit after shutdown.
